column2: SEVEN IDEAS THAT SHOOK THE UNIVERSE
column6: Description of major revolutionary physical concepts and their implications for understanding the physical universe. Not counted toward physics major.
A course integrating basic concepts in chemistry, physics and astronomy.

To provide a nurturing course for new physics majors, ideally to be taken in their first semester as majors. The course includes a journal club component, informational talks by industrial physicists and training in a select group of essential skills and tools for future work in the physics program.

Basic physics applied to health technologies: measurement techniques, force and motion of solids and fluids, energy, heat wave phenomena, electricity. Students taking this course should be in a health technologies major.

column4: MATH 11010; and pre- or corequisite: MATH 11022 or MATH 19001.
column6: Introduction to principles of physics: mechanics. Two-hour lecture/recitation and two- hours laboratory weekly.
Introduction to principles of physics: fluids, thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism. Three-hour lecture/recitation and two-hour laboratory weekly.

Laboratory-lecture course designed to introduce the computer scientist to the digital logic and memory circuits and the concepts fundamental to computer hardware. Two hours lecture, two hours lab weekly.
Principles of mechanics, heat and sound. Three-hour lecture, one-hour recitation. Pre- or corequisite: MATH 11022 or 12002 or 12021. Corequisite: PHY 13021.
Principles of electricity and magnetism, optics and modern physics. Three hours lecture and one hour recitation weekly.

column5: MATH 11022 or 12002 or 12012 or 12021. Corequisite: PHY 13021.
column6: Principles of classical physics, primarily mechanics. Three-hour lecture and one-hour recitation weekly. This is a flexibly scheduled course that meets concurrently with PHY 13001 for the first half of the regular term. Pre/corequisite: MATH 11022 or 12002 or 12012 or 12021. Corequisite: PHY 13021.

Principles of classical physics, primarily electricity and magnetism. Three-hour lecture and one-hour recitation weekly. This is a flexibly scheduled course that meets concurrently with PHY 13002 for the first half of a regular term.
Introductory lab to accompany PHY 13001 or PHY 13011. Corequisite: PHY 13001 or PHY 13011.
Introductory lab to accompany PHY 13002 or PHY 13012. Corequisite: PHY 13002 or PHY 13012.
Topic announced when scheduled.

column2: PHYSICS IN ENTERTAINMENT AND THE ARTS
column6: Descriptive introduction to physics underlying selected forms of art and entertainment. Examples are drawn from music visual arts and communications media. Not counted toward requirements for major in physics.

column2: PHYSICS IN ENTERTAINMENT AND THE ARTS LABORATORY
column6: Laboratory component of PHY 21040, two hours weekly. Pre- or corequisite: PHY 21040.
Modern description of astrophysical observations, the results of these observations and the physical principles based on them. Not counted toward requirements for major in physics.
Laboratory component of PHY 21430 Frontiers in Astronomy. This course may be used to satisfy the Kent Core requirements. Pre- or corequisite: PHY 21430.

Survey of mechanical and electronic properties of materials with application in science and technology. Metals, semiconductors, ceramics, polymers and liquid crystals, and other special materials will be addressed.

Fundamental physical concepts are related to various forensic activities including evidence analysis, ballistics, auto collision analysis and radioactive materials accidents. Three hours lecture, two hours lab weekly.
Principles of mechanics, heat and sound at calculus level. Four hours lecture/recitation and three hours lab weekly. Pre- or corequisite MATH 12002.
Principles of electricity, magnetism, light and modern physics at calculus level. Four hours lecture/ recitation and three-hour lab weekly.

Astronomical measurements and their instruments, the solar system of planets, the sun and stars, spectra, radiation, evolution of stars, galaxies, concepts of cosmology. Course not counted toward physics major.
(Repeated registration permissible) Experiments in classical and modern physics are selected to accompany and to supplement junior-level physics courses.
Topic announced when scheduled.
"Hands-on" course to give the student a working knowledge of analog electronics and of AC and DC circuits typically used by the scientist.
Multispeed aerodynamics including topics in fluid mechanics, airfoil and wing theory, stability and control, performance and aerodynamic loads.

This course will provide a quantitative introduction to modern cosmology, from the Big Bang to the formation of the first stars. Subjects include the evolution of the geometry and temperature of the universe its composition and select aspects of general relativity.

Modern description of mechanics including both Lagrangian and Hamilton formulations, with applications to central force, motion, coupled oscillations, rigid body motion and motion in non- inertial reference frames.
Special theory of relativity, Rutherford-Bohr model of atom, quantization of light, matter waves, Schroedinger equation, hydrogen atom, electron spin, multi-electron atoms.

Survey of applications of twentieth century physics. Topics include molecular bonding, conducting and insulating solids, degenerate matter, quantum condensates, subatomic and sub-nuclear particle physics, cosmology.

column4: PHY 30020; and pre- or corequisite: 6 credit hours of 40000-level physics courses.
column6: Advanced experiments in classical and modern physics are selected to accompany and to supplement senior-level physics courses. Repeated registration permitted.
Study of current or topical literature.

Supervised capstone experience in physics at a national laboratory, a research university in industry or at a local research site. Repeat registration permitted. No more than 3 credit hours may be applied toward the major electives for physics majors.
Workshop individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of physics. S u graded.
Topic announced when scheduled.

column4: 20 hours of physics; and special approval of department chairperson.
column6: Individual projects for physics majors.

column4: Honors senior standing and special approval.
column6: Thesis for departmental, general or university honors must be 1-10 hours with continuous registration throughout the senior year beginning in the summer prior to the senior year. Students taking this course must consult with their department and the Honors College and receive approval prior to the first semester of the senior year.
Topic announced when scheduled.

Interdisciplinary overview of the basics of biophotonics; application of biophotonic techniques to probe biological samples. Introduction to the foundations of optics and photonics and how the molecular structure of organic molecules translates into unique photonic properties and targeting in biological cells or tissue. Preparation of fluorescent materials, advanced spectroscopy and cell visualization using regular and confocal fluorescence microscopy.

column2: PHYSICS OF LABORATORY DEVICES AND TECHNIQUES
column6: Physics of semiconducting devices such as diodes, transistors; laboratory techniques using temperature control, vacuum pumps; X-ray, neutron, light and electron scattering.

Laboratory-based course in digital and analog electronics, computer interfacing and computer-based technique all within context of applications in measurements, signal-to-noise enhancement and control instrumentation. Lecture two hours, lab four hours weekly.

Introduces ideas essential to physical understanding of biological systems. Topics include: introduction to molecular components of the cell; statistical mechanics and transport in biological systems; selected topics in biophysics.
Galactic structure, stellar formation and evolution, origin of the elements (or nucleosynthesis), non-optical astronomies, and description of various cosmological theories.
Properties of electric and magnetic fields developed by vector methods. Treatment on static fields in vacuum and matter. Theory of classical electromagnetic fields with emphasis on dynamic fields.
An introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, with applications in material science and engineering.

Consolidation of vector analysis, curvilinear coordinate systems, tensors, matrix algebra, vector spaces, common groups in physics, calculus of residues, contour integration, methods for differential equations in physics; additional topics important for physics selected from special functions, integral equations, calculus of variations.

column2: DATA ANALYSIS AND COMPUTATIONAL PHYSICS TECHNIQUES
column6: Study of uncertainties in physical measurements. Data reduction and error analysis techniques. Monte Carlo simulation method. Least-squares fits to data. Basic computational physics techniques.
Interactions between light and matter from both a macroscopic and microscopic perspective; producing and controlling light devices and spectroscopic techniques based on modern optics.
Bohr theory, wave mechanics, wave packets. Applications to barriers, oscillators, hydrogen atom, multi-electron atoms, X-rays, molecular spectra. At level of Eisberg-Resnick's quantum physics.

Introduction to the concepts of nuclear physics including basic properties of the atomic nucleus, experimental techniques, nuclear models and reactions, nuclear fission and fusion, and elementary particles.
Fundamental unifying concepts and experimental techniques needed to understand thermal, electrical and optical properties of ions and electrons in solids. Special topics of current research.
Advanced experiments in classical and modern physics are selected to accompany and to supplement graduate-level physics courses. Repeated registration allowed.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of physics.
Topic announced when scheduled.
Individual projects for physics graduate students.
Topic announced when scheduled.

Interdisciplinary overview of the basics of biophotonics; application of biophotonic techniques to probe biological samples. Introduction to the foundations of optics and photonics and how the molecular structure of organic molecules translates into unique photonic properties and targeting in biological cells or tissue. Preparation of fluorescent materials, advanced spectroscopy and cell visualization using regular and confocal fluorescence microscopy.

column2: PHYSICS OF LABORATORY DEVICES AND TECHNIQUES
column6: Physics of semiconducting devices such as diodes, transistors; laboratory techniques using temperature control, vacuum pumps; x-ray, neutron, light and electron scattering.

Laboratory-based course in digital and analog electronics. Computer interfacing and computer- based technique all within context of applications in measurements signal-to-noise enhancement and control instrumentation. Lecture two hours, laboratory four hours weekly.
Planetarium operation, advantages and limitations. Slides, technamation, special effects and programs for K-12 grades, public and special groups.

Introduces ideas essential to physical understanding of biological systems. Topics include: introduction to molecular components of the cell; statistical mechanics and transport in biological systems; selected topics in biophysics.
Galactic structure, stellar formation and evolution, origin of the elements (or nucleosynthesis), non optical astronomies, and a description of various cosmological theories.
Properties of electric and magnetic fields developed by vector methods. Treatment of static fields in vacuum and matter. Theory of classical electromagnetic fields with emphasis on dynamic fields.
An introduction to thermodynamics and statistical mechanics, with applications in material science and engineering.

Consolidation of vector analysis, curvilinear coordinate systems, tensors, matrix algebra, vector spaces, common groups in physics, calculus of residues, contour integration, methods for differential equations in physics; additional topics important for physics selected from special functions, integral equations, calculus of variations.

column2: DATA ANALYSIS AND COMPUTATIONAL PHYSICS TECHNIQUES
column4: MATH 12003 and PHY 23102 and graduate standing.
column6: Study of uncertainties in physical measurements. Data reduction and error analysis techniques. Monte Carlo simulation method. Least-squares fits to data. Basic computational physics techniques.
Interactions between light and matter from both a macroscopic and microscopic perspective; producing and controlling light devices and spectroscopics on techniques based on modern optics.
Bohr theory, wave mechanics, wave packets. Application to barriers, oscillators, hydrogen atoms, multi-electron atoms, x-rays, molecular spectra. At level of Eisberg-Resnick's quantum physics.

column4: PHY 36001 and graduate standing. Pre- or corequisite: MATH 32052.
column6: Introduction to the concepts of nuclear physics including basic properties of the atomic nucleus, experimental techniques, nuclear models and reactions, nuclear fission and fusion, and elementary particles.
Fundamental unifying concepts and experimental techniques needed to understand thermal, electrical and optical properties of ions and electrons in solids. Special topics of current research.
Discussion of current literature or of original research in physics. Participation by students, faculty and guests.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of physics.
Methodology of teaching in a university, college or junior college. Includes observation of kinds of teaching and practice teaching.
Research or individual investigation. Credits earned may be applied toward meeting degree requirements if department approves. Repeated registration permitted.

column4: Special approval of adviser and graduate standing.
column6: Thesis students must register for total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Selected special topics of current research interest.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree requirements are met.
Selected special topics of current research interest.

column4: PHY 6/75101 or PHY 6/75203 or PHY 6/76161 or PHY 6/75301 or departmental instructor approval. Graduate standing.
column6: The course imparts advanced problem-solving skills not acquired in regular courses. Examples from four basic areas of physics (classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics and statistical physics) will be emphasized.
Lagrange's equations, variational principles two body central force problems rigid body motion Hamilton's equations canonical transformations Hamilton Jacobi theory small, oscillations.
Introduction to electrostatics, boundary value problems multipoles electrostatics of macroscopic media magnetostatics time varying fields Maxwell's equations conservation laws.
Plane electromagnetic waves, simple radiating systems, scattering, special theory of relativity, relativistic dynamics, radiation of moving charges, Bremsstrahlung.
An introduction to statistical mechanics, including classical and quantum statistics. Derives thermodynamic quantities from a statistical viewpoint.

Fundamental concepts of non-relativistic quantum mechanics. Solution of simple one dimensional problems. Abstract Hilbert-space description. Matrix representations. Quantum dynamics. Extension to three dimensions. Spin and orbital angular momentum.

Angular momentum theory. Symmetries and conservation laws. Application of approximation methods to realistic problems. Systems of identical particles. Scattering theory. Relativistic single particle wave equations.

Discussion of particle detectors, invariance principles, and conservation laws, fundamental interactions, quark model of hadrons, basic concepts of field theory, the Standard Model and selected topics of current interest.
Theory of nuclear processes including properties of nuclear quantum states, two-body forces, nuclear structure and models, nuclear reactions and nuclear radiation physics.
Advanced concepts and theories of nuclear interactions. Topics include the nucleon interaction, nuclear structure, reactions, nuclear matter and strong interactions of elementary particles.

Crystalline state, with emphasis on wave propagation, zone and band theory, phonons. Applications to electrical and thermal conductivities, specific heats, optical, dielectric and magnetic properties.

column4: PHY 6/76401 and PHY 6/76161; and graduate standing.
column6: Covers several topics including conduction in metals, dielectric and ferroelectric properties, the origin of magnetism, phenomenological and BCS descriptions of superconductivity, elastic theory and semiconductor physics.
Advanced theories of solids, fluids, superfluids, magnetic, ferroelectric and liquid crystal systems and the experimental methods that probe them.

column4: Graduate standing in physics or chemical physics.
column6: The molecular structure and properties of liquid crystals and their role in biological systems and industrial applications.
Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of physics.
Methodology of teaching in a university, college or junior college. Includes observation of kinds of teaching and practice teaching.

column4: PHY 6/75101 or PHY 6/75203 or PHY 6/76161 or PHY 6/75301; or departmental instructor approval. Doctoral standing.
column6: The course imparts advanced problem-solving skills not acquired in regular courses. Examples from four basic areas of physics (classical mechanics, electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics and statistical physics) will be emphasized.
Lagrange's equations, variational principles, two-body central force problems, rigid body motion, Hamilton's equations, canonical transformations, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, small oscillations.
Introduction to electrostatics, boundary value problems, multipoles, electrostatics of macroscopic media, magnetostatics, time-varying fields, Maxwell's equations, conservation laws.
Plane electromagnetic waves, simple radiating systems, scattering special theory of relativity, relativistic dynamics, radiation of moving charges, Bremsstrahlung.
An introduction to statistical mechanics, including classical and quantum statistics. Derives thermodynamic quantities from a statistical viewpoint.
Classical and quantum statistics with emphasis on Fermi and Bose systems. Introduction to approximate methods including cluster expansions and virial coefficients. Applications to critical phenomena.

Fundamental concepts of non-relativistic quantum mechanics. Solution of simple one dimensional problems. Abstract Hilbert space description. Matrix representations. Quantum dynamics. Extension to three dimensions. Spin and orbital angular momentum.

Angular momentum theory. Symmetries and conservation laws. Application of approximation methods to realistic problems. Systems of identical particles. Scattering theory. Relativistic single particle wave equations.
Second quantization and field theory formalism are developed for the many-particle system. Topics include the electron gas and nuclear matter.

Discussion of particle detectors, invariance principles and conservation laws fundamental interactions quark model of hadrons basic concepts of field theory the standard model and selected topics of current interest.

column4: PHY 56101 or equivalent or permission. Doctoral standing.
column6: Theory of nuclear processes including properties of nuclear quantum states, two body forces nuclear structure and models nuclear reactions and nuclear radiation physics.
Advanced concepts and theories of nuclear interactions. Topics include the nucleon on interaction nuclear structure reactions nuclear matter and strong interactions of elementary particles.
Crystalline state, with emphasis on wave propagation zone and band theory phonons. Applications to electrical and thermal conductivities specific heats optical dielectric and magnetic properties.

column4: PHY 6 76401 and PHY 6 76161 and doctoral standing.
column6: Covers several topics including conduction in metals, dielectric and ferroelectric properties the origin of magnetism phenomenological and BCS descriptions of superconductivity elastic theory and semiconductor physics.
Advanced theories of solids, fluids superfluids magnetic ferroelectric and liquid crystal systems and the experimental methods that probe them.

column4: Doctoral standing in physics or chemical physics.
column6: The molecular structure and properties of liquid crystals and their role in biological systems and industrial applications.
Discussion of current literature or of original research in physics. Participation by students faculty and guests.

Presentation by invited speakers of research and other topics on graduate level followed by discussion period. Regular attendance of all physics majors expected. Three or more meetings each semester as arranged.
Research or individual investigation for doctoral students who have not yet passed their candidacy exams. Credit earned may be applied toward the degree if the department approves.

Doctoral dissertation, for which registration in at least two semesters is required first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree requirements are met.
Discussions of current literature or of original research in chemical physics. Participation by students faculty and guests.
